Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism of Distant Communication in Chromatin

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: The first step in gene expression (RNA synthesis, or transcription) of the vast majority of eukaryotic genes is regulated by enhancers, which are DNA sequences that bind specific proteins and activate transcription over large distances. Enhancer-target communication (ETC) leads to direct interaction of enhancers with the target promoters, the sites of transcription initiation, via formation of a DNA loop. ETC can be prevented by insulators, which are DNA elements that form alternative DNA loops and can isolate enhancers from the targets. Thus, gene regulation in human cells involves formation of DNA loops of variable sizes. The mechanisms of efficient communication between enhancers and promoters and the mechanisms by which such communication is prevented by insulators remain unknown. In particular, neither structural nor dynamic aspects of DNA looping have been rationalized. Recently, it has been shown that DNA loops bound to histone proteins are a highly efficient communication device. These observations indicate that ETC could constitute a critical step in gene regulation and raise the following important questions: What elements of the DNA-histone complexes mediate efficient ETC, and how can ETC be inhibited or facilitated by various factors? In this project, a highly purified and functionally active experimental system has been established that allows quantitative analysis of the rate of ETC in the DNA-histone complexes. This system will be used as a tool to analyze structural and dynamic properties of the DNA-histone complexes that dictate the rate of ETC. The objectives of this research are to evaluate the mechanisms of efficient distant communication and inhibition of communication by insulators and to identify factors affecting distant communication and evaluate their effect on the dynamics of the DNA-histone complexes.
Broader impacts: This project will provide an enhanced learning experience for several undergraduate and two graduate students involved in the project. They will participate weekly in four different meetings; namely (1) laboratory meetings in which they will have the opportunity to present their own research every 2-3 months, (2) laboratory discussion of recent publications on chromatin structure/dynamics/function, (3) problem solving sessions with a small group of students and senior researchers that focuses on technical challenges, and (4) Departmental Progress Reports where all Departmental students present their research annually. This project is well suited for student participation, as it provides a solid conceptual foundation and utilizes methodologies applicable to many areas of research, and at the same time is paradigm-driven, providing an intuitive transition from the classroom to the bench. The laboratory regularly trains underrepresented minority undergraduates (within the UMDNJ Summer Research Program). New technologies/strategies for analysis of structure/dynamics of the DNA-histone complexes will be developed. Some of them will be of general use in the field of biology. The project is a multi- disciplinary study to examine a complex biological question, and incorporates recent advances in computational science and structural biology at the interface between chemistry, physics and biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human genes are tightly regulated, and the primary regulation occurs at the first step – when RNA is made on the DNA template. Recently it was discovered that in large part this regulation is done through relatively short DNA sequences called enhancers that bind specific proteins and typically regulate genes over a large distance along DNA. Since nearly all human DNA is covered by other proteins (histones) that tightly compact DNA in the small volume of cell nucleus, the important question is: How can enhancers reach over the large stretches of histone-covered DNA to regulate the target genes? Our research project was dedicated to analysis of the role played by various proteins and DNA sequences in distant gene regulation by enhancers.

Our theoretical analysis has shown that in order to explain efficient enhancer action over a distance, one needs to explain how histone-covered DNA can make large loops that bring together enhancers and the regulated genes. To study such looping, in a collaborative studies with Drs. Sengupta and Wilma from Rutgers University we have conducted computational simulations of the structure and dynamics histone-covered DNA. We have shown that while loop formation is not in itself sufficient to explain action at a distance, incorporating transient interactions between different regions of histone-covered DNA strongly enhances long-distance regulatory interactions. It has been established that histone-covered DNA is an intrinsically dynamic structure that can support long-range communication. We have established that the transient interactions between different regions of histone-covered DNA occur through both histone-histone and histone-DNA contacts, and identified candidate histone and DNA regions involved in the interactions.

To experimentally evaluate the candidate histone and DNA regions involved in gene regulation over a distance by enhancers, we have developed a defined and relatively simple approach using highly purified DNA and proteins that can be studied in test tube. In these studies we have confirmed the predictions of the computational studies, and have identified additional non-histone proteins and their regions involved in looping of histone-covered DNA. We have also shown that the presence of histone-free DNA regions can strongly affect the efficiency and the rate of the looping. We then continued analysis of the looping in a model organism – the fruit fly. This analysis has confirmed our primary conclusions.

The mechanisms of distant gene regulation discovered in our studies likely share important features and intermediates with the mechanisms utilized during various other cellular processes involving distant interactions between DNA regions [such as DNA replication (duplication of DNA helix) and repair, and genome rearrangements]. Therefore the results of this study are likely to be relevant for a wide variety of related fields in molecular biology and biochemistry. Our work provides a framework for understanding and further analysis of the mechanisms of these processes. The methods developed during these studies are also likely to be important for these studies.

Changes in distant gene regulation are intimately involved and often determine development of various human diseases. Since misregulation of enhancer action is associated with numerous human diseases including thalassaemias, Hirschsprung’s disease and cancers, our studies will lead to better understanding of the development of these diseases and will help to develop new strategies and drugs for their treatment.
